Research

My research investigates algebraic structures and their geometric manifestations, with an eye toward questions motivated by representation theory and secure communication. I am especially interested in the behavior of algebraic groups and monoids, geometric representation theory, and algebraic methods for coding theory.

Current areas

  • Algebraic groups and monoids: structure, classification, compactifications, and invariant theory.
  • Representation theory: unitary representations, harmonic analysis, and categorical approaches.
  • Algebraic geometry: birational techniques and singularities with applications to representation theory.
  • Error-correcting codes and security: algebraic and geometric constructions for robust communication.

Collaborations & lab

I lead the QSPARC Lab, a laboratory at Tulane University focused on algebraic approaches to secure communication and coding theory. The lab pairs theoretical research with experimentation, including work with SDR radios and post-quantum protocols.
